comments.commentBody: The problem is  that immigration law gives preference to family members over skilled workers.

Please have the hospital executive contact his/her Congressional representative about your situation.  And if nothing happens, contact the representative again and again and again. You are EXACTLY the type of person who deserves help.

Jack, I suggest you immediately consult with a qualified immigration lawyer like Carl Shusterman in Los Angeles, who routinely handles physician cases. Evidently you are on an H-1B or J-1 visa. Unless you are on a J-1 with a 2-year foreign residency requirement, I see no reason for you not to have applied for a Green Card and have no idea why you would make a comment like: "I'm still on a visa without a green card in sight."

And I especially have no idea how you can say, "My Hospital is desperately trying to hire another physician but no American will work out here in the wilderness." If there are no US physicians willing to work there, since you are, you are the perfect candidate for a Labor Certification and adjustment to permanent residence . . . . . but then you know that.

I wonder why are you failing to reveal the real reason your employing hospital is not sponsoring you in a Labor Certification.

I am an immigrant Physician from India who took a job in the deep Midwest where none of the locals cared to work. My spot had been empty for years. I turned down (slightly) lesser paying jobs in NY and California, as I felt a debt to the people of Iowa, who had trained me as a Physician. I have been in this country for 8 years and pay a tax of about $40K a year alone in federal taxes and I'm still on a visa without a green card in sight. My Hospital is desperately trying to hire another physician but no American will work out here in the wilderness. My staff and Nurses love me and I'm sorely needed here-but do the people who run this country understand that? I don't feel entitled and I don't think America owes me anything; In fact I owe America a lot. I understand that, but I don't understand how you can break every rule in the book and still come out ahead. That is not an American trait.

Why? What have you got to lose? Areas wher immigrants live do much better that depressed American inner cities.

If all immigrants could fly home or on vacation, it would also improve the airline businesses.
Immigrants are way more likely to start new businesses and create new jobs. I can speak for myself and I have created lots of working alternatives.

By largely freeing us from rodent-borne disease, cats have likely saved more lives than medical science. Where I grew up, our cats roamed free, and brought in 50 rats for every bird they caught. As often as not, we could intervene and save the bird (the cats were so proud of these rare avian catches, they often brought them home unharmed), but we were glad to see the rats go. Rats are also omnivores and amazing tree-climbers. The 50 rats, loose but for our cats, would have killed far more than one bird.

Wherever people go without cats, rats run free and multiply. Several readers have mentioned Europe's experiment eliminating those 'satanic' cats, and the deadly plague that followed. When I worked in Boston's Chinatown, it was largely free of roaming cats, but chock-full of rats. I would often see rivers of rats pouring from trash cans when my car headlights shined on them at night.

Poison the rats instead of using cats? Not nearly as effective, because the rats must first find and eat the poison, with plenty of other food sources around. Cats, on the other hand, can stalk and catch rats hundreds of feet away. Poisons also indiscriminately kill hawks, ospreys, snakes, and other animals that naturally hunt rodents.

There are excellent, life-saving reasons why humans have lived with outdoor cats for thousands of years. Ignore them at your peril. It is foolish to imagine that but for cats, we would have only more cute, harmless, fuzzy, little creatures.

Important to clarify that the cats I'm referring to live in rural environments, farming areas with plenty of room and food sources. It is of course often far different for cats that live in urban environments, but the cats that live in urban environments are not creating the problems associated with wildlife predation.

One of our cats, and I use the term 'our' loosely because she lived on her own, in a barn, with very little support from humans. She was a friendly female, who could be petted and picked up by someone familiar, but she chose to live independently, separate from the other cats who largely relied on us for their survival on the farm. She lived exclusively by hunting, except during the harshest winters. She understood instinctively there were already too many cats in that area, so she abandoned her litters of kittens in open fields soon after birth. One of which I found in a soybean field and raised as a house pet, but he also had a fiercely independent streak, disappearing for days or weeks at a time, roaming the area looking for females on other Farms.

His mother of which I speak lived for over 25 years, whereas our average indoor outdoor house cats on the farm lived for 15 to 18 years at best. But as any human will tell you, quality of life is far more important than quantity. Any cat given the choice, chooses freedom over captivity. No surprise that some humans don't understand this preference, since so many choose a life of captive slavery themselves.

What do you call people who break into your home while you are away? Undocumented homeowners? When the police say, "They're here now so they are entitled to stay", are you okay with that? When they take your cars without permssion, is that okay? After all, they are not thieves, they are just undocumented car owners. If they take your children, are they 'undocumented' parents'? The term 'illegal alien' means that someone is someplace illegally (without permission) and is an unnaturalized foreign resident. You might find the word pedophiles dehumanizing, too--perhaps you prefer 'lovers of children'. People who break laws are illegals.

G.W. Bush and John McCain both pushed hard for immigration reform (I assume you want God to bless them, too, as well as Reagan). Obama has thrown out the term 'immigration reform' but done nothing so far. Let's just hope that he lets Congress take the lead and resists the urge to sabotage the plans.

Immigrants come here legally
Illegal aliens sneak across the border.
huge difference
Are we really at the point where asking people to obey our immigration and employment laws is akin to Nazism?

God bless our humane and compassionate President.

There are those, usually Republicans, who refer to undocumented immigrants (the correct term) as illegal aliens.

That unfortunate term is dehumanizing and fosters cruelty. The fascists of WWII did everything they could to dehumanize those they wanted to be rid of. We know what that led to.

I heartily agree with your position about healthier indoor cats--and you didn't even mention the range of parasites they pick up outside. By keeping my five rescued cats indoors, I save nearly $1000 a year in anti-parasitics/pesticides alone. Then, of course there are all the other afflictions you mention in your post--plus, we have a booming population of coyotes here in southern Indiana.

Faced with my firm determination, even my wildest cats stopped protesting their confinement in pretty short order. They are now entertained by the bird feeders all day, as viewed through the patio door. Everyone in my purview is safer and healthier--inside and outside, domestic and wild. I am criticized by some for not allowing them to roam, but I feel not one iota of recrimination.

I have some experience with feral cats and their caretakers, too. Though these creatures require much more patience and problem-solving challenges, I have encountered many stories of contented confinement solutions for them, too.

Dorothy's dog after a trip to the Caribbean:
TANTOTO

(Tanto: much, used in music, like presto non tanto, )
I think of it as being on a ship that is trying to be rescued from slowly sinking while the captain sends out a call to "climb aboard!".
Obama has had NO budget for the past 4 years.....this too is against the law, but what does he care
Law abiding citizens clearly don't matter to our elected reps. All that matters is catering to the Latino lobby. If Americans are punished as a result no one really cares.

What will happen to those citizens and legal residents who are currently unemployed? How are we going to extend our support to them and their families? After the illegal aliens become citizens they will bring in their extended families legally and who is going to pay for their health care and nursing homes? Can our president and our country really provide  for so many people in the almost over-the-cliff economy? Is Mr. Obama even able to balance his budget at all? Politicians need votes but we people need to live in a society with a viable economy!
And where is the market for those drugs? You make it sound so simple. it isn't. I wonder how you would feel if you were one of the victims? You might then realize that 'they' are humans.

@ Jennifer.

There are probably at least 200 million people that might fall under the category of what we might deem ‘victim hood’. Just look to one area of the world… Africa, and its many failed states, where people are victims of endemic poverty, illiteracy, religious and tribal violence, and unsustainable cultural proclivities like very high fertility rates.

Should the US open its borders to them? If it did, it would spell this country’s doom. If we took them in, another 100 or so million (easily that amount) would claim the same status, and cry “Foul” if we didn’t open our doors to them also.

Poverty, crime, and oppression occur in Asia, Mexico, and Central and South America, effecting many millions. Should we open the doors to them too?

The US, Canada, some European countries, and Australia are magnets for the poor and uneducated because these countries are welfare states. This is not 100 years ago when the US population was less than one third what it is now, and when a growing US needed more people, and when the US taxpayer wasn’t burdened with providing these legal immigrants with social services.

Enough is enough.

Let 11-20 million Hispanics or white eastern Europeans illegally habituate, (and take jobs) in and around Cape Town, and let’s see the response (open arms?) from South Africans of all ethnicities. The response would be far less benign than that of the US… I have no doubt.

Sadly, you are all missing the point. This is not an argument about Mexico, drugs or future amnesty for illegals. This is all about the lack of the US government's enforcement of its own immigration laws over a period of more than 20 years, which encouraged illegals to come to work for unscrupulous US employers who wanted to save a buck. Don't blame the illegals - you would have done the same if you were in their situation - blame the US government, the US immigration Service, Congress and the employers who knowingly violated US laws in hiring the illegals.

Now, what is being proposed is to give amnesty to those who came across the border to get the carrot at the end of the stick the government and employers offered.

The government cannot tolerate 11 million illegals living in the shadows not paying taxes and living a sub-standard life with no way out and it cannot afford to deport them.

So, what is your suggestion? Hitler's "final solution"?

Get serious here.

At this very moment there is a sharp increase in the numbers of Central Americans working their way through Mexico and on their way here right now.

The "drug war" has turned their countries into chaos.

This migration wave is just getting started and is expected to send several million more before it is over. Will they be included in this amnesty or in the next amnesty?

But Obama and the Dems want a permanent voting block of illegals coming here for free stuff.

Who are we to deny them?

I find it truly remarkable how ignorant the comments here are. Do you people really take yourselves seriously? If you did, you would become more knowlegeable about this topic before you embarrass yourselves further.

Wake-up America!  Remember when President Reagan allowed 3 million illegals to become citizens? Another 11 million more came to the United States illegally!  So, look for another 11 million or more to follow!  We haven't learned anything from the past.
I am quite sure that American citizens would work for the farmers if the farmers paid decent wages.

There is nobody more awful to represent than such Boards and the people who sit on such boards and argue with each other over trifles.  It gets really nasty, and always about trifles.  It is much like divorce work, in the emotions that take over good sense.  Those lawyers willing to do it always have awful stories, good for a laugh until you think about seriously dealing with these people.
Tired of this kind of arrogant comment

You will always need people who make and deliver actual things. The dotcom collapse 20 years ago was about exactly this. 'We'll do everything over the internet!' Well, no. And I think if we are honest with ourselves, we put up with a lot of inconvenience and complication because we've been sold the online bill of goods. (Much the same with hardware. If the same expectations with regard to malfunctions, DIY troubleshooting, and unreliability were applied to your car as to your computer, who'd drive? We expect a lot more dependability from our cars, but put up with a lot of bugs with regard to software.)
@sunny  Who do you think is in "we"?  A bunch of "I's" are in it, that's who.  No single "I" working alone accomplishes very much.
may i add that some of those who are NOT  "smart, technically savvy and well capitalized" have at least as much value, interest and simple human kindness to offer the rest of us, than those who ARE.

'Yes, You Can,' boosts private and individual action. 'Yes, You Must,' hints at dystopian outcomes.  The downside of a hyper-connected, hyper-capitalized, hyper-competitive world are the many who will be left by the wayside.  Not everyone is smart, technically savvy and well-capitalized.  Those who aren't need a safety net.

There used to be billions Passenger Pigeons in North America until the "introduced species" of European invaders wiped them out in less than 200 years. It could take a whole day for one flock to pass overhead.

Fascinating to me that a majority of responses defend cats as just doing what comes "naturally" when they are an introduced species protected by our culture, our health care system, and various laws. The answer, they argue, is for humans to stop impacting other species like birds so negatively.

Perhaps the cat supporters wouldn't mind, then, if we established a more truly "natural," and hands-off environment for their pets to enjoy. Along with eliminating habitat loss for wild birds, we could scratch vaccinations and veterinarians for cats, and make sure that pathogens from the old world were in amply supply over here. Then we could expunge humane laws, since it's not "natural" to protect these little hunters from trauma or mistreatment by other mammals, including us. No such laws in the wild. Finally, we should encourage coyotes and other natural predators of cats to enter cats' current habitats with a similarly Darwinian frame of mind, and obey their instincts too. What's that? Not so interested in natural behavior after all, just in privileging one species that purrs at the cost of many others?
Thank you

SC, right on. And thank you.
"A house divided cannot stand," as Lincoln so well-stated. The die was cast for an American Civil War once Jefferson authored a Declaration of Independence that pointedly excluded an end to slavery. And, as a few of the founders did accurately prophesy in 1787, the Constitution's failure to end slavery led directly to the Civil War. Americans by the 1850s had a decision to make: Either America lives up to its ideals and grants freedom to all, or the entire nation, as you say, would endure as a "defacto slave" country. I saw the horrors of slavery, behind Burmese Army lines in 1992 and 2002. And there is nothing more joyful than looking in the eyes of a child whose life you have saved, I reckon; looking in the eyes of the Karen hill tribe children whom we freed from Burmese Army slave labor patrols was beautiful beyond words. Slavery is an abomination in our time and was most certainly hell on earth for African-Americans in Lincoln's time, until he ended it. And thank God for Grant and Lincoln and Buford and Chamberlin.

Mike Tucker
Visiting Scholar on Counterterrorism, US Naval Academy

"Upon military necessity" did Lincoln issue his emancipation proclamation. Why? To supress a rebellion against the Union.

Who rebelled? Deep South secessionist plantation class legislators. Why? To maintain and expand the basis of their economy--slavery.

Did private citizen Lincoln sit back and watch idly from the sidelines in the 1850s as the fugitive slave laws (and later, the Dred Scott decision) turned all of the US into a defacto slave state? No.

Would President Lincoln have emancipated slaves for other than military necessity in response to rebellion? No.

The Deep South secessionists brought it on, and Abraham Lincoln responded . . . and he prevailed. How? By responding, legally, to the military necessities before him.

And why did restoration of the Union lead to preservation of the Union? Because he acted also as a humanitarian: with charity for all, with malice toward none.

I love it when Howie references pop music one-hit wonders of the 80s!

Oh, and BROmide is A+ material.
In this puzzle SAL would be SAL MINEOEO.

Rijkstra:

By the time scientists get around to cloning the popular '50s actor, he'll be known as Sal Mimeo! ;)

62D has me wondering whether SAL is a ammoniac, ammoniac on the floor and he's dancing like he's never danced before?
Rather than Fratricide, CAIN slaying ones brother be classified more ABELy as a case of BROmide?
On a AJARing note, I once dated a GOGOL girl I met at a DISCO Bar, of course, she ran me ragged!
Will Nediger, Next time, WEED prefer to EDAM than weep, which is the LETHE I can say.

Many ACMES for this Hump Day offering delivered in PEAK condition

SKOAL, Howie
laws are not enforced, AZ tried and obama took them to court...he wants the illegal aliens here to vote for his 3rd Term

I agree Louweegie. The reason there are 11 million illegals is before the government did not enforce employer sanctions and then later, during the G.W. Bush Administration, they began to enforce the laws against violating US employers, they were crucified in the press.

With regard to Barb Tennant's comment, I'm afraid she does not understand the difference between US immigration law, preempts all state laws, and what the Arizona law was designed to do. Further, Obama cannot run for a 3rd terms. I wonder if Barb is on this planet when it comes to immigration and political issues.

Why should we believe that immigration laws will ever be enforced?  We were told in 1986 that the "one time amnesty" would be the last, new laws were written, NAFTA happened and the immigration mess increased 5 fold. Now we are supposed to believe that the government will get serious about the already written laws once we are forced to accept another amnesty?    Can you say "failed state"?

A LOT of people thought the break-up of the eurozone was coming. I remember the cover of The Economist having the title of 'The End of the Euro' or something like that. Had Syriza gotten a couple more votes than it would have broken up.

Just because Europeans in the periphery have been surprisingly willing to take so much hardship does not mean any of these predictions are wrong. The PIIGS will have to go through decades of austerity to pay off their debt (especially Greece). People won't be willing to live in a terrible economy for decades just because they like the currency and status they get from being a eurozone member.

Very soon in one of the PIIGS (and France could join this list soon) an anti-bailout party will win an election and reject the austerity measures imposed by the troika. If that doesn't end it there (perhaps the troika bows down to their demands) than later on, at some point the government will default on their debt. Austerity is simply the transfer of wealth from the people to the banks who hold government bonds (creditors) and profit from the high yields. At some point people will decide they are done paying and this country will pull an Argentina (or a Russia).

These studies always "scale up" incorrectly by attributing what happens in populated areas of study to the wild. And by the way, in rural areas, farmers want cats around to keep pests under control. Unfortunately those same farmers are probably not feeding or altering those animals. That is much different than a trap-neuter-return colony. I have had many cats over the years and some are not suited to be indoors fulltime. Many of those cats have been virtually non-hunters or poor hunters. And no doubt, many bird enthusiasts would be happy to have cats kill non-native bird species because they have stated they "hate" them.
Certainly, in areas where endangered species of birds or other critters are more common, it would be best to not have domesticated cats roaming about there, but that is just not the case for most indoor-outdoor pet cats or TNR colonies. There are differences between truly feral cats, TNR colonies, and parttime outdoor cats. And a well-fed cat that ages will not roam as much, hunt as much, or even go outside as much. It's the younger cats that do the most hunting & spay/neuter would help reduce their numbers. The truly feral cats are often loners and become part of the food chain.

We always get travel insurance when we travel, and we recommend it to our travelers. At the very least, basic medical and evacuation insurance is a must, and it costs $58 if you're 60. It can cost $100,000 to be evacuated out of some of the places we go and send people: the middle of Siberia, the center of the African continent, the coast of Costa Rica. Who has that kind of money handy? And it has nothing to do with age. A young person can blow out a knee, as my husband did, on a trip to Prague. Our expenses were $8,000 -- all covered up front by our excellent travel insurance, Travelex. An older person might have to be evacuated from the Trans-Siberian Express, as we had to arrange. That was 10 years ago, and the cost was $75,000. The trick to travel insurance is to use a reliable company, such as Travelex, which we use personally and recommend to our travelers. Things to ask: does it cover pre-existing conditions? Does it cover all ages? Is it primary insurance? Does it have a human I or my loved ones can talk to in case of medical emergency to plot my evacuation? Is there a person I can call to buy it -- AND the same person to talk to if I have a claim and need back-up? Save yourself a lot of trouble. Consider travel insurance a cost of your trip. www.irtsociety.com

They are not real people.  They were fictional individuals who were entered on insurance company websites, so they have no credit ratings.  Insurance company can't check the credit ratings of people who don't really exist.

Bird conspiracy?  Tell that to the dead hummingbird that was snatched before our eyes by the neighbor's black cat.  I say that if these deadly felines are to be forever released upon us, we should have the right to defend our property and the wildlife therein with lethal force.
What nonsense! Conspiracy? You take the extreme example of Douphine and act as if that is the norm. It would be as if stating that all cat owners are hoarders with hundreds of cats!

This "story" is part of a grotesque, carefully coordinated media campaign carried out for more than 15 years by the American Bird Conservancy, The Wildlife Society, taxpayer-funded staff at the US Fish and Wildlife Service and the Smithsonian, and fellow travelers in the academy such as Marra and "researchers" at the University of Georgia. One of the latter was Nico Dauphine, convicted last year of attempted cruelty for trying to poison cats. She not only got her graduate degree from Georgia . . . she worked at the National Zoo, which is part of the Smithsonian.

There is nothing on the cat advocacy side to compare with the wealth, power, and media access of these groups. The anti-catters were able to drop a press release and see numerous stories in blue-chip media outlets appear within 24 hours. Against this, cat advocates are virtually powerless.

It's important to note that the one thing the anti-cat cabal does NOT want to do is help birds. Birds are being destroyed by pollution, herbicides, pesticides, habitat destruction, habitat fragmentation, and global warming. All of the economic groups that bring these forces to bear on birds are extremely well defended by lobbyists. The anti-catters know perfectly well they can't win against Big Agriculture, Big Chemistry, an endless array of industrial polluters, and the development lobby. That's why they attack cats: cats can't defend themselves.

Shame on Angier for doing this, and shame on her editors for letting her.

For this issue, we need strong leadership from people in power like Mayor Bloomberg.

I think that placing a ban on free roaming cats is not only the environmentally conscionable thing to do, but reasonable as well. People have demonstrated that they cannot voluntarily do the right thing; a local ordinance or policy seems like a good fix to force them into proper behavior.

I think perhaps a dual purpose bill that includes mandatory spay/neuter for domestic cats in case they ever do get out of the home.
